Hi O3. I'm interested in making a useful prompt to explore a literature review with Deep Research subsequent to this conversation. 

To begin, here's a draft of what I was working on the other day:
```
Levenson’s multidimensional Locus of Control model exhibits three orthagonal scales of how an individual interprets their agency and expectancy mapped to past and future events. We have drawn inspiration from Rotter and Levenson’s discussion of the idea of a Locus of Control continuum by mapping it to our observed behaviours and expectations around the use of LLMs by students and staff.  

We propose two coupled dimensions – not orthogonal – that of internal/external (I-E), and that of agnostic/informed (A-I). The informed side of the A-I dimension is so tightly coupled to the internal/external scale as to identify with it. This continuum can be described with three extreme states (pure internal, pure external, pure agnostic), but most individuals and their models-of-AI should be better understood to occupy regions (depending on situational and tool context) between these extremes. 

The I-E scale allows us to frame expectations of an individual’s expectation of agency when prompting or engaging with the outputs of LLMs. Note, this does not imply a technical mastery around training or deploying these systems, merely in engaging with them via prompting and other interfaces once deployed.  

AI-Internal Locus Attributes 

We could describe the extreme internal user as one that views their words to these things as programming using textual tools, and who evaluates their own responses to the tool outputs as part of a feedback loop to improve their own prompting. They feel they have maximum agency in using these tools, despite the “stochastic parrot” nature of the output, and they are able to exercise judgement about what tool, what interface to use and what output to accept based on their own expertise. In Vinge’s words, they have “learned how to ask the right questions” and “know something about something.” More to the point, they have learned how to take a present-at-hand perspective with regards to these tools which respond “I” -- they are able to “see past” the chat interface, and to have established and predictable expectations about what input would cause what sort of output. To be clear, we view this position as a good and desirable interaction outcome, albeit one that takes time, training, and expertise, just like any other discipline mastery. This stance is described by Jack Clark: 

“	[…] in the era where these AI systems are true 'everything machines', people will out-compete one another by being increasingly bold and agentic (pun intended!) in how they use these systems, rather than in developing specific technical skills to interface with the systems. ... 

We should all intuitively understand that none of this will be fair. Curiosity and the mindset of being curious and trying a lot of stuff is neither evenly distributed or generally nurtured. Therefore, I'm coming around to the idea that one of the greatest risks lying ahead of us will be the social disruptions that arrive when the new winners of the AI revolution are made - and the winners will be those people who have exercised a whole bunch of curiosity with the AI systems available to them.” 

 

AI-External Attributes 

We could describe the extreme external user as being extremely informed (as per the agnostic/informed axis), just as the internal user is, but with an utter passivity in terms of agency.  Here, this user resonates more with AI qua Adams’ “Plastic pal who is fun to be with” -- they engage with these chatbots as friends or as supplicants. For example, when there are claims that “AI is creating a generation of illiterate programmers”, such that: 

 “First, I stopped reading documentation. Why bother when AI could explain things instantly? 

Then, my debugging skills took the hit. Stack traces now feel unapproachable without AI. I don’t even read error messages anymore, I just copy and paste them. 

I’ve become a human clipboard, a mere intermediary between my code and an LLM.  

Previously, every error message used to teach me something. Now? The solution appears magically, and I learn nothing. The dopamine hit of instant answers has replaced the satisfaction of genuine understanding.” 

The extreme-external position on the continuum is “acting as a human clipboard” -- but, crucially, with full choice in model and tool. Here, this user knows what they are doing, and chooses to abdicate agency in accomplishing their tasks, thinking their choice of tools is sufficient. Students in this mode are either opting out of the rituals of education (either for time-pragmatic reasons or because they view the exercise as a necessary but irrelevant one) or view their personal capabilities at the time as overstretched. In one of the chat transcripts in our dataset, a student said “have I addressed the "political factors" section of the question? PLEASE be honest!!! I am so stressed out because I am tired and this is due. ... [multiple prompts] ... so like the political factors are broad? idk hbb!!! I am so stressed like I am so stressed 😭”  

Here, the student has clearly set up, earlier in the chat, their task and has chosen their model with intention. However, due to exhaustion, stress, and a lack of time, they are engaging with Claude as the “plastic pal who is fun to be with” and getting (useful) explanation and emotional support in their task. The student has resigned their agency in the actual chat but still exhibits intentionality over their choice to use the model and has engaged pragmatically with this mode of academic and emotional support. To be clear, later in this chat, the student is engaging with the AI to critique the student’s output, so this exchange is not an example of an extreme-external user.  

AI-Agnostic Attributes 

The quintessential example of the extreme external user is the one in the quote above, who chooses the tool and acts as a human clipboard. A student who pastes the entire assessment into the chatbot in their first prompt, takes the output, and submits it without the text ever deeply interacting with their thoughts, is quite high in the external end of the agency scale, but is also quite likely somewhere higher up the agnostic scale. Students engaging in this trivial copy-paste behavior likely have very little knowledge of which tools to use to achieve their desired objectives, instead engaging with these systems by rote, recommendation, or advertisement.  

The extreme-agnostic scale represents a different failure mode. This is a mode where the individual is agnostic as to the specific facts of Large Language Models – specifically that they do not have enough information or knowledge to judge the current state of affairs beyond the stories-of-AI which comprise western media and stories-of-LLMs which are repeated in news stories. “Skynet on a Roomba” is our way of representing their confusion as to the presence and capabilities of current chatbots and LLMs. This extreme position has an epistemological and ontological position on the technology absent of any informed use of the technology. Instead, people in this position respond to other peoples’ use of AI as part of a status game (TODO QUOTE) where a different person or their own hypothetical use of the technology devalues their own work as a blanket statement and/or is engaging with these things only in the engagement of the stories of these things, i.e. promoting/protesting their ability to automate workers out of jobs, engaging with consultants who sell them untested products, or expecting a self-aware goal-setting and goal-achieving machine intelligence to both exist and to allow the current world to exist within some recognizable context, without a good understanding of the present capabilities of the these tools. In a different class supported by Ballsun-Stanton with assessment design and a few recorded supplemental lectures, but without a class-wide focus on AI, a student said: “I have this whole philosophical objection to AI -- [students] shouldn’t use unoriginal work it’s really bad for society.”  

This sort of blanket condemnation is an entirely valid position to take but perfectly represents an agnostic position around capabilities. The student, with their ontological claims, does not engage in any aspect of the capabilities of LLMs, instead lumping all interfaces and all models into their opposition. As educators, unfortunately, we cannot take or enforce this position as we cannot make rules we cannot enforce. Therefore, for sheer pragmatic reasons, we cannot recommend ignorance-of-specific-capabilities as an appropriate stance. Knowledge of specific failure modes, problems, and the constraints of a given interface or model, allows for more specific, articulate, and persuasive responses to the inappropriate introduction of LLMs and their associated chatbot interfaces.  

 

Internality-Agnostic Continuum 

 

Internality-Externality Continuum 

 

Agnostic-Externality Continuum 

 

 

Middle AI-Internal/Agnostic 

Middle AI-External/Agnostic 

Middle AI-Internal/External 

Exact Centre 
```

I have a number of comments with citations in this document, but what I'd like you to do is to think about what concepts require coverage in a literature review. 

From a quality perspective, my instructions to you are: "We're looking for a comprehensive, but deep literature review. Make sure to please evaluate source and author quality before inclusion, it is *ESSENTIAL* you focus on high-quality publications and avoid those from paper mills and predatory journals. Blogs are acceptable if the author is known in the field or has a high quality research output otherwise."

Before we begin, help me to refine and ask questions for this prompt. My objective is to have deep research do this lit review, but I want to make sure the problem case is well defined. Formatting wise, this should be a formal academic literature review that could appear in a major q1 journal.

**Refining research prompt**

The user wants guidance to refine their approach to exploring a literature review with Deep Research. They’ve provided a draft involving Levenson’s multidimensional Locus of Control model applied to student and staff use of LLMs, particularly focusing on the internal/external and agnostic/informed dimensions. They’re asking for help to refine their prompt and ensure the research problem is clearly defined. The goal is a formal academic literature review, suitable for a major journal. I’ll help in shaping the prompt by considering key questions.

**Refining literature review prompt**

To refine the problem, I need to generate a comprehensive set of questions. These should clarify dimensions, definitions, and the theoretical framework. I’ll ask about constructs like agency, locus of control, and expectations in LLM use, and get details on research aims, boundaries, timeline, and inclusion criteria. I’ll cover aspects like databases to use, quality of sources, and whether a systematic review or meta-analysis is preferred. I'll also check if grey literature is needed and elements like Q1 journal requirements. These questions will help define a clear, well-structured literature review prompt.

parts:
Below is a set of refinement questions and suggestions that you might consider before initiating your deep research literature review. These points are designed to ensure that the prompt is well defined, the scope is precise, and the subsequent review meets the standards of a formal academic piece suitable for a major Q1 journal.

---

### 1. **Clarifying the Research Focus and Scope**

- **Theoretical Foundation:**  
  - *Which existing theoretical models do you consider foundational?*  
    For instance, do you want to focus primarily on Levenson’s multidimensional Locus of Control model and Rotter’s work, or do you plan to incorporate other theories of agency and expectancy from psychology and human-computer interaction?
  
- **Dimensions and Constructs:**  
  - *How do you plan to operationalize the two coupled dimensions (internal/external and agnostic/informed)?*  
    Should the review provide a detailed conceptual analysis of these dimensions, or are you also interested in empirical studies that have measured these constructs in the context of LLM usage?

- **Contextual Boundaries:**  
  - *What is the specific context of interest?*  
    You mention students and staff interacting with LLMs—do you intend to cover literature from education, cognitive science, and human-computer interaction, or focus on one particular domain?
  
- **Temporal and Disciplinary Limits:**  
  - *Are there any publication date ranges or disciplinary boundaries to consider?*  
    For example, should the review prioritize recent research (given the rapid evolution of AI technologies) while also connecting to historical psychological literature?

---

### 2. **Methodological Considerations**

- **Search Strategy and Source Evaluation:**  
  - *What criteria will you use to assess the quality of sources?*  
    It is essential to specify the metrics for source selection (e.g., journal impact factor, citation count, reputational standing of the author) and the databases (e.g., Web of Science, Scopus) to be searched.
  - *How will you handle grey literature, such as blogs?*  
    Define the conditions under which a blog post is acceptable (e.g., when the author is a well-known expert with high-quality research output).

- **Inclusion and Exclusion Criteria:**  
  - *What will be the specific inclusion and exclusion criteria?*  
    Consider detailing criteria that will help avoid predatory journals and paper mills while ensuring that the selected literature is both comprehensive and of high quality.

- **Review Structure:**  
  - *How should the review be organized?*  
    Would you prefer a thematic organization (e.g., sections on internality, externality, and agnosticism) or a chronological review of the evolution of these concepts?

---

### 3. **Substantive Content and Thematic Questions**

- **Conceptual Clarification:**  
  - *What are the underlying assumptions about “agency” and “expectancy” in the context of LLM use?*  
    It might be useful to articulate how these concepts are understood within both psychological and computational frameworks.
  
- **Comparison of User Archetypes:**  
  - *How should the literature review differentiate among the three extreme states (pure internal, pure external, pure agnostic) and the mixed or middle states?*  
    Is there existing literature that explores these archetypes in other domains that might inform your review?

- **Implications for Educational and Technological Practices:**  
  - *What are the broader implications of these user positions on educational outcomes, digital literacy, and technology adoption?*  
    Identifying these implications early can help guide the selection of literature and ensure the review remains grounded in practical significance.

- **Potential Criticisms and Limitations:**  
  - *What critiques exist regarding the application of locus of control models to technology usage?*  
    Should the review include a section that critically examines alternative perspectives or the limitations of applying these psychological constructs to LLM interactions?

---

### 4. **Formatting and Academic Standards**

- **Style and Presentation:**  
  - *How should the final review be formatted?*  
    Specify whether you expect adherence to a particular style guide (e.g., APA, Chicago) and ensure that the narrative is formal, logically structured, and meets the expectations of a Q1 journal.

- **Depth and Breadth:**  
  - *What is the desired balance between depth and breadth?*  
    Should the review offer a deep dive into a few high-impact studies, or aim to cover a wide array of studies and perspectives to build a comprehensive theoretical framework?

---

### 5. **Sample Refined Prompt**

To help consolidate these considerations, here’s an example of a refined prompt:

> **Refined Prompt for a Literature Review:**  
> "Conduct a comprehensive literature review suitable for publication in a major Q1 journal, focusing on the application of locus of control models—particularly Levenson’s multidimensional model and Rotter’s conceptualizations—to the use of large language models (LLMs) by students and staff. The review should critically examine the dual dimensions of internal/external agency and agnostic/informed engagement, exploring both theoretical and empirical contributions from psychology, human-computer interaction, and educational technology. Emphasize high-quality sources from reputable journals, and include select grey literature (e.g., influential blog posts) only when authored by recognized experts. The review should (a) define and operationalize the core constructs, (b) evaluate existing measurement approaches and empirical findings, (c) compare extreme and mixed user archetypes, and (d) discuss the broader implications for educational practices and technology adoption. Sources must be carefully vetted to avoid predatory or low-quality publications, and the narrative should adhere to [specified style guide]."

---

By addressing these questions and integrating the answers into your prompt, you can ensure that the subsequent deep research will be both rigorous and well-tailored to your objectives. Would you like to elaborate on any particular point or need further assistance refining any part of this prompt?

parts:
Below is an expanded, numbered hierarchical outline of refined questions you can use to shape your literature review prompt. This outline is organized into major sections with sub-questions for easy reference.

---

### 1. Clarifying the Research Focus and Scope

1.1. **Theoretical Foundation**  
    1.1.1. Which foundational theoretical models (e.g., Levenson’s multidimensional Locus of Control, Rotter’s conceptualizations) should be included?  
    1.1.2. Should alternative or complementary psychological theories of agency, expectancy, and control be incorporated?  
    1.1.3. How do these theories intersect with concepts in human–computer interaction and digital literacy?

1.2. **Dimensions and Constructs**  
    1.2.1. How should the two coupled dimensions—internal/external and agnostic/informed—be defined and operationalized?  
    1.2.2. Is the review intended to focus solely on conceptual definitions, or should it also encompass empirical measurement and validation studies?  
    1.2.3. What are the expected behavioral outcomes or user archetypes associated with each extreme and intermediate state?

1.3. **Contextual Boundaries**  
    1.3.1. What is the primary context (e.g., educational settings, professional environments, general public use) for the application of LLMs?  
    1.3.2. Should the focus be exclusively on students and staff, or is there merit in considering other user groups?  
    1.3.3. How might the domain (e.g., education, HCI, cognitive science) influence the interpretation of agency and expectancy?

1.4. **Temporal and Disciplinary Limits**  
    1.4.1. What publication date range is relevant given the rapid evolution of AI technologies?  
    1.4.2. Which academic disciplines should be prioritized in the review?  
    1.4.3. Should historical perspectives on locus of control be contrasted with recent advancements in AI usage?

---

### 2. Methodological Considerations

2.1. **Search Strategy and Source Evaluation**  
    2.1.1. Which academic databases (e.g., Web of Science, Scopus, IEEE Xplore) should be used for the literature search?  
    2.1.2. What metrics (e.g., journal impact factor, citation counts, peer-review status) will be used to assess source quality?  
    2.1.3. Under what conditions should grey literature (such as blogs) be included, and how will the authority of the author be verified?

2.2. **Inclusion and Exclusion Criteria**  
    2.2.1. What are the specific criteria for including high-quality publications?  
    2.2.2. How will predatory journals and paper mills be identified and excluded?  
    2.2.3. Are there any types of literature (e.g., non-peer-reviewed sources) that should be excluded outright?

2.3. **Review Structure**  
    2.3.1. Should the review be organized thematically (e.g., by conceptual frameworks, empirical findings) or chronologically?  
    2.3.2. How should the structure balance the discussion of conceptual underpinnings with empirical evidence?  
    2.3.3. What sections (e.g., methodology, discussion, critique) are necessary to meet Q1 journal standards?

---

### 3. Substantive Content and Thematic Questions

3.1. **Conceptual Clarification**  
    3.1.1. How is “agency” defined in the context of LLM usage?  
    3.1.2. What are the underlying assumptions about “expectancy” and related constructs in existing literature?  
    3.1.3. How do different fields (psychology, HCI, education) conceptualize these terms?

3.2. **User Archetypes and Behavioral Dimensions**  
    3.2.1. How should the extreme user states (pure internal, pure external, pure agnostic) be characterized?  
    3.2.2. What empirical evidence exists for the presence of mixed or intermediate user archetypes?  
    3.2.3. How do individual differences in user behavior correlate with the observed outcomes in LLM interactions?

3.3. **Empirical Evidence and Measurement Approaches**  
    3.3.1. Which studies have empirically measured these constructs in the context of LLM usage?  
    3.3.2. What methodologies have proven effective in capturing user agency and control?  
    3.3.3. Are there any validated scales or instruments that can be referenced or adapted?

3.4. **Implications for Educational Practices and Technology Adoption**  
    3.4.1. How do different user positions (internal vs. external, informed vs. agnostic) impact educational outcomes?  
    3.4.2. What are the broader societal implications of these user dynamics on digital literacy and technology adoption?  
    3.4.3. What potential challenges or benefits do these interactions pose for educators and policymakers?

3.5. **Critiques and Limitations**  
    3.5.1. What are the limitations of applying traditional locus of control models to modern LLM interactions?  
    3.5.2. What alternative frameworks or critiques exist in the literature?  
    3.5.3. How do these critiques inform the interpretation of user agency and expectancy in the context of LLM usage?

3.6. **Ethical and Social Considerations**  
    3.6.1. What ethical issues arise from the reliance on LLMs in educational and professional settings?  
    3.6.2. How do issues like bias, accountability, and the digital divide intersect with user behavior in LLM interactions?  
    3.6.3. What recommendations does the literature provide to address these ethical concerns?

---

### 4. Formatting and Academic Standards

4.1. **Style and Presentation**  
    4.1.1. Which style guide (e.g., APA, Chicago) should be followed for formatting and citation?  
    4.1.2. What are the expectations regarding tone, formality, and clarity for a Q1 journal submission?

4.2. **Depth versus Breadth of Coverage**  
    4.2.1. Should the review emphasize a deep dive into a few seminal studies or provide a broad overview of the literature?  
    4.2.2. How can the review effectively balance historical context with the latest research trends?

4.3. **Citations and Source Quality**  
    4.3.1. What standards of citation are required to ensure transparency and reproducibility?  
    4.3.2. How will the review document the vetting process for high-quality sources?

---

### 5. Additional Considerations

5.1. **Future Research Directions**  
    5.1.1. What gaps in the current literature should be highlighted for future investigation?  
    5.1.2. How can the review propose actionable research questions or areas for further study?

5.2. **Practical Recommendations**  
    5.2.1. What actionable insights can be derived from the review for educators, technologists, and policymakers?  
    5.2.2. How should the review address the translation of theoretical insights into practical guidelines for LLM usage?

---

This comprehensive, numbered outline should serve as a robust guide to ensure your prompt is well-defined, covers all necessary aspects, and adheres to the academic standards expected in a Q1 journal submission. Feel free to adjust or expand upon any section to better suit your specific research objectives.

1.1.1 Levenson and Rotter (especially in the literature discussion beyond them, and the application to pedagogically relevant HCI discussions).

And they are reliant on text in a way that is directly linked to the skills and methods that we emphasize in university humanities classes." -- I'm making a link between the textual and prompting here. 1.3.3 Sorry, say again?

1.4.1 For Rotter et al from the 60's. This is more around technology pedagogy, less so about AI.
1.4.2 Ed Psych
1.4.3 only if they involve conversations around the adoption and comprehension and mastery of technology within the learner's context.

2.1.1 Whatever you have access to, but please focus on academic databases as you have access. If you need me to find the full text of papers, please pause and ask for my input.
2.1.2 Scimago search. If it's q1, it's fine. Below that, evaluate within the context of the quality of papers. Emerging journals are fine, predatory are not.
2.2.3. No, much of this should be the evaluation of the author, rather than the source. Prefer peer reviewed overwhelmingly.

2.3 Thematically
2.3.1 Even balance.
2.3.3 Coherency, and quality of journal and citations. The articles we engage with may be from the humanities as well as the sciences.

3.1.1 Good question. How is agency defined with other technologies? If this is a novel use for us, we'll need to find a new one.
3.1.2. Please find any discussion of this, we might have to work on it if you cannot find this in the literature.
3.1.3 Please research an answer for this.

3.2 Out of scope. I want you only to do a lit review.

3.3 See if there's anything, please.
3.4.1 Out of scope, but see if there's anything that "rhymes" from other ed psych research on the teaching of other technologies. (With special attention to the teaching of calculator use in the 70's-80's and the change to powerpoint presentations in the 2000's. 
3.4.2 See if there's any literature

3.6 Out of scope.

Do you think I'm ready to push the deep research button?

**Evaluating deep research readiness**

Looking at their clarifications, it seems like they’ve really refined their instructions and questions. So, based on everything, yeah, I'd say they’re ready to move forward! 1. **Theoretical Foundations and Comparative Documents:**  
   - You’ve specified the focus on Levenson and Rotter with an emphasis on their application to pedagogically relevant HCI discussions.  
   - You’ve also clearly indicated that a separate document should examine competing framings, evaluating their strengths and weaknesses for possible adoption.

2. **Dimensions and Constructs:**  
   - The operationalization of internal/external and agnostic/informed has been set, with a particular interest in mapping these to agency, passivity, and rote behavior.  
   - You requested a scholastic critique of the literature resonance for these constructs, which will support the subsequent discussion based on experimental results.

3. **Context and Disciplinary Boundaries:**  
   - The context is clearly focused on the pedagogy of AI within university settings, specifically addressing adult learners and skill acquisition.
   - The historical perspective (e.g., Rotter from the 60s) will be included only insofar as it relates to technology pedagogy rather than AI specifically.

4. **Methodological Considerations:**  
   - You’ve defined the quality criteria (using Scimago rankings, focusing on Q1 and peer-reviewed journals) and the search strategy, emphasizing academic databases.
   - Inclusion criteria are set to prioritize peer-reviewed sources, with author evaluation taking precedence over the source in some cases.

5. **Review Structure and Formatting:**  
   - The review will be organized thematically, ensuring an even balance and maintaining academic rigor per APA style, with a formal narrative style that avoids casual formatting features.
   - An annotated bibliography with notes on source quality is expected for easy review, along with an appendix noting any research gaps.

6. **Scope:**  
   - You’ve clearly defined what is in scope (e.g., theoretical definitions, empirical evidence where available) and what is out of scope (e.g., practical recommendations, user archetypes, broad implications) for the literature review.

Given this level of specificity and the comprehensive nature of your instructions, you are indeed ready to push the deep research button. The next step would be to initiate the literature search and compile the review according to these guidelines.

Would you like me to proceed with initiating the deep research process based on these refined instructions?

I will now begin the deep research process based on your refined instructions. Given the complexity of this literature review, I will break it down into multiple structured outputs:

1. **Primary Literature Review Document** - Focused on Levenson and Rotter’s models, their application to pedagogically relevant HCI discussions, and resonance with AI pedagogy.
2. **Comparative Theoretical Analysis Document** - Evaluating competing theoretical framings, assessing whether they are better or worse, and making a case for or against their adoption.
3. **Scholastic Critique Document** - A critical academic evaluation of the constructs and dimensions you proposed, considering literature resonance.
4. **Annotated Bibliography** - A structured list of high-quality sources with notes on relevance, credibility, and key insights.
5. **Research Gaps Appendix** - Identifying any missing discussions in the existing literature that warrant further research.

I will ensure adherence to your methodology, focusing on Q1 journals and peer-reviewed sources, with special attention to Ed Psych and historical discussions on pedagogy and technology (e.g., calculator adoption, PowerPoint in education). 

Before proceeding, do you have any final refinements or additional requests?

Great! I will now conduct a deep literature review on your specified topics, ensuring a high standard of academic rigor and relevance. The research will be structured into multiple documents, covering:

1. **Primary Literature Review** – Examining Levenson and Rotter’s models, their application in pedagogically relevant HCI, and resonance with AI pedagogy.
2. **Comparative Theoretical Analysis** – Evaluating competing models, assessing their strengths and weaknesses, and arguing for or against their adoption.
3. **Scholastic Critique** – Analyzing the validity of your constructs (internal/external, agnostic/informed) in light of existing literature.
4. **Annotated Bibliography** – Providing source evaluations with insights on credibility and relevance.
5. **Research Gaps Appendix** – Identifying missing discussions and future research directions.

I will ensure all sources are from reputable academic databases, prioritizing Q1 journals and high-quality peer-reviewed sources. I will update you once the research is ready for review.

3. **Scholastic Critique:**
   - Critically evaluate the proposed dimensions (internal/external, agnostic/informed) based on existing literature.
